title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the hillside in Northern Manhattan where the northern dusky salamanders are found?

options.label: A
options.text: It is one of the last areas in the city where there's clean spring water.

options.label: B
options.text: It is one of the largest areas in the city where there's clean spring water.

options.label: C
options.text: It is one of the most polluted areas in the city.

options.label: D
options.text: It is one of the most urbanized areas in the city.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the challenges faced by the northern dusky salamanders in Northern Manhattan?

options.label: A
options.text: They are being hunted by predators.

options.label: B
options.text: They are being divided by bridges and infrastructure.

options.label: C
options.text: They are being affected by climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: They are being affected by pollution.

multiple-choice.question: What is the white-footed mouse used as a model for in the study of urban environments?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how species are adapting to urban environments.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how species are migrating to urban environments.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how species are interacting with each other in urban environments.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how species are evolving in urban environments.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of sequencing thousands of genes from city mice and comparing them to thousands of genes from country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand how genes are changing in urban environments.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how species are adapting to urban environments.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how genes are affecting the biology of mice in urban environments.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how genes are influencing the behavior of mice in urban environments.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Manhattan plot in the study of urban environments?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the genetic diversity of mice in urban environments.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the genetic differences between city and country mice.

options.label: C
options.text: It represents the genetic changes that occur in mice as they adapt to urban environments.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the genetic variations that occur in mice in urban environments.

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

multiple-choice.question: What concept did Malcolm McLean envision in 1937 that would revolutionize the shipping industry?

options.label: A
options.text: Containerization

options.label: B
options.text: Break bulk shipping

options.label: C
options.text: Bulk cargo shipping

options.label: D
options.text: Freight forwarding

multiple-choice.question: What was Malcolm McLean's occupation at the age of 24, when he got a job to transport cotton bales from North Carolina to New Jersey?

options.label: A
options.text: Truck driver

options.label: B
options.text: Ship captain

options.label: C
options.text: Warehouse worker

options.label: D
options.text: Customs broker

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Malcolm McLean's first container ship, which sailed from Port Newark in 1956?

options.label: A
options.text: Ideal X

options.label: B
options.text: Container King

options.label: C
options.text: Shipping Pioneer

options.label: D
options.text: Bulk Buster

multiple-choice.question: What was the main problem that Malcolm McLean encountered while working as a truck driver in 1937?

options.label: A
options.text: He was bored with the work

options.label: B
options.text: He was frustrated with the slow loading and unloading process

options.label: C
options.text: He was unhappy with his salary

options.label: D
options.text: He was dissatisfied with the truck's performance

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of containerization on the global marketplace?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduced the variety of goods available

options.label: B
options.text: It increased the cost of shipping

options.label: C
options.text: It offered an infinite variety of things

options.label: D
options.text: It slowed down the movement of cargo

title: Poetic stickup: Put the financial aid in the bag - Carvens Lissaint

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker ask everyone to do at the beginning of the skit?

options.label: A
options.text: Put their hands on their heads and stay calm.

options.label: B
options.text: Put their hands down and participate.

options.label: C
options.text: Run all the financial aid and put the scholarships in the bag.

options.label: D
options.text: Get the Pell Grants and subsidized loans.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main concern in the skit?

options.label: A
options.text: Getting financial aid for education.

options.label: B
options.text: Being called crazy.

options.label: C
options.text: Getting money for their ancestors.

options.label: D
options.text: Getting guns for self-defense.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker referencing when they mention "Professor Willie Lynch"?

options.label: A
options.text: A famous educator who helped them with their education.

options.label: B
options.text: A professor who taught them about financial aid.

options.label: C
options.text: A historical figure who taught the principles of oppression.

options.label: D
options.text: A politician who helped them with their degree.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in the skit?

options.label: A
options.text: To get money for their ancestors.

options.label: B
options.text: To fight for the opportunity that their great-great-great-grandfather died for.

options.label: C
options.text: To get their education and learn.

options.label: D
options.text: To get guns for self-defense.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's tone in the skit?

options.label: A
options.text: Calm and respectful.

options.label: B
options.text: Angry and frustrated.

options.label: C
options.text: Happy and excited.

options.label: D
options.text: Sad and depressed.

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the problem with using $10 words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too long and difficult to pronounce.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not understood by the audience.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not creative and fail to convey the intended meaning.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not used in everyday conversation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writing when the audience is not captive?

options.label: A
options.text: Use as many $10 words as possible to impress them.

options.label: B
options.text: Write at a fourth-grade reading level to reach a wider audience.

options.label: C
options.text: Use brevity and get to the point to hold their attention.

options.label: D
options.text: Use humor and try to be funny to keep them engaged.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's comparison between using $10 words and having a Scrabble board?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a fun way to learn new words, but not practical for writing.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a waste of money, but a good way to impress friends.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a way to save money and buy a more useful tool for writing.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to show off one's vocabulary, but not useful for writing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's argument against using $10 words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not creative and fail to convey the intended meaning.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not understood by the audience and are rendered worthless.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too long and difficult to pronounce.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not used in everyday conversation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writing in a world with shrinking attention spans?

options.label: A
options.text: Use as many $10 words as possible to impress the audience.

options.label: B
options.text: Write at a fourth-grade reading level to reach a wider audience.

options.label: C
options.text: Use brevity and get to the point to hold the audience's attention.

options.label: D
options.text: Use humor and try to be funny to keep the audience engaged.

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a partnership between two different species, such as bees and flowers?

options.label: A
options.text: Mutualism

options.label: B
options.text: Symbiosis

options.label: C
options.text: Coexistence

options.label: D
options.text: Competition

multiple-choice.question: What do squirrels do with the cones from the upper branches of the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: They eat them

options.label: B
options.text: They bury them in piles, or middens

options.label: C
options.text: They climb the tree to reach the cones

options.label: D
options.text: They ignore them

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way the Clark's nutcracker stores seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: It stores them in its nest

options.label: B
options.text: It stores them in a pouch in its throat

options.label: C
options.text: It stores them in the ground

options.label: D
options.text: It stores them in a tree

multiple-choice.question: What do the Clark's nutcrackers use to remember where they cached their seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: Their sense of smell

options.label: B
options.text: Landmarks on the landscape

options.label: C
options.text: A map

options.label: D
options.text: A compass

multiple-choice.question: What has evolved in the Clark's nutcracker to help it gather seeds from the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: A longer, more agile body

options.label: B
options.text: A long, tough beak

options.label: C
options.text: Stronger wings

options.label: D
options.text: A sharper vision

title: How many universes are there? - Chris Anderson

multiple-choice.question: If the Milky Way galaxy has enough stars to fill a 30 foot by 30 foot stretch of beach three feet deep with sand, how deep would a beach need to be to represent the stars in the entire universe?

options.label: A
options.text: A few feet deep

options.label: B
options.text: A few hundred feet deep

options.label: C
options.text: Hundreds of millions of miles deep

options.label: D
options.text: Thousands of miles deep

multiple-choice.question: According to recent theories in physics, including string theory, how many universes could exist in the multiverse?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 10 universes

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 100 universes

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 10 to the 500 universes

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 100 billion universes

multiple-choice.question: What is the leading version of string theory predicting about the multiverse?

options.label: A
options.text: A multiverse made of up to 10 universes

options.label: B
options.text: A multiverse made of up to 100 universes

options.label: C
options.text: A multiverse made of up to 10 to the 500 universes

options.label: D
options.text: A multiverse made of up to 100 billion universes

multiple-choice.question: According to some physicists, what is the space-time continuum made of?

options.label: A
options.text: A finite number of universes

options.label: B
options.text: An infinite number of universes

options.label: C
options.text: A multiverse made of up to 10 to the 500 universes

options.label: D
options.text: A single universe

multiple-choice.question: What is the theory of quantum mechanics suggesting about the creation of parallel universes?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are not being spawned every moment

options.label: B
options.text: That they are being spawned every moment, and many of these universes would be very like the world we're in

options.label: C
options.text: That they are being spawned every moment, but none of these universes would be like the world we're in

options.label: D
options.text: That they are not being spawned every moment, but some of these universes would be like the world we're in

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the conversation between Richard Feynman and his father about the ball going to the back of the wagon?

options.label: A
options.text: It introduced the concept of gravity.

options.label: B
options.text: It introduced the concept of inertia.

options.label: C
options.text: It introduced the concept of relativity.

options.label: D
options.text: It introduced the concept of quantum mechanics.

multiple-choice.question: What was the experiment that Galileo and his assistant conducted to determine whether or not light had a speed?

options.label: A
options.text: They measured the time it took for a ball to roll down a hill.

options.label: B
options.text: They measured the time it took for a lamp to be lit and the light to travel a certain distance.

options.label: C
options.text: They measured the time it took for a shadow to fall on a surface.

options.label: D
options.text: They measured the time it took for a sound to travel a certain distance.

multiple-choice.question: What was the key innovation that Armand Fizeau used to measure the speed of light?

options.label: A
options.text: He used a telescope to magnify the light beam.

options.label: B
options.text: He used a prism to split the light beam into its components.

options.label: C
options.text: He used a toothed wheel to send discrete pulses of light.

options.label: D
options.text: He used a mirror to reflect the light beam.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Eratosthenes' calculation of the Earth's diameter?

options.label: A
options.text: He calculated it to be 10,000 miles.

options.label: B
options.text: He calculated it to be 25,000 miles.

options.label: C
options.text: He calculated it to be 40,000 miles.

options.label: D
options.text: He calculated it to be 50,000 miles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the story of how scientists have made discoveries throughout history?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that scientists are always right.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that scientists are always wrong.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that scientists are human and can make mistakes.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that scientists are not curious.
